posts.name: Anonymous
posts.sub: Books on becoming your true self
posts.com:
I notice in alot of people, notably famous celebrities and internet personalities, they all have a very distinct almost cartoonish persona.
A particular voice, a particular appearance that is so distinct and characteristic of them that you recognize it instantly and it's unforgettable.

But these people did not begin like this, when you look at their earlier work they appear less so distinct. Perhaps there is a hint of that character in there. But as they grow as a person or perhaps as they become more famous and confident in themselves, that character becomes bolder.
Some of these celebrities' personas become so extreme that it would be almost off-putting to see them in real life becuase they no longer look like a normal person.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
And I should mention that I'm not talking about any sort of "becoming your best self" or anything like that. This "true self" persona can be very bad if that's what it is.
When people are children, they all appear the same, but as they grow up, their unique character appears.. but you can see the seeds of it in their younger years, they are just not developed.
We're all shaped by our experiences in life, but it seems that in some people, this true self that they're seemingly destined to be never emerges. They are shy.

If you've ever watched someone on the internet whether it's a youtuber or a livestreamer you'll notice how their early work is very bad. Their voice is monotone, their face appears indistinct, they use very uninteresting vernacular.
But as they grow in popularity and you see them again with a million followers, they appear much more distinctive. Even their face appears like a cariacatured version of their previous self. Their voice is distinct, they use strange words and phrases that are quotable "a classic x line" people say.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
But it seems that this persona can only appear when the person in question is confident in themselves. When they are free of shyness, when they no longer feel like they have to fit in to society but instead become an individual.

And I also wonder if it can go in reverse. Can a person who has developed that persona.. through some huge failure in life revert back to that uninteresting average joe with no distinct qualities?

I haven't read any philosophy but I ask here because I have a feeling this is a topic that someone must have written about. I hear alot of "awakening to your true self and becoming an individual" talk when people speak of philosophy

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Perhaps a good comparison would be the development of an artists art style.
When you look at their early work, it is hard to tell it apart from other artists, but as they develop and discover what sort of artist they want to be, as they become confident in their own stylistic choices, they reveal a more and more distinct style that is unmistakingly theres.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Also I'm not looking for books on "how to" become your true self. I'm not into all that self help shit. I just want to read about someone exploring the topic as a concept of this thing that happens to people

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21590720
>your true self
What does that mean in this context? I'm actually curious what you have to say on this.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21591261
Like there's a potential within you for what sort of person you could be. Based on your own experiences, unique quirks, talents, etc. But for whatever reason you're shy and don't express it.
But if you become more confident, you can allow that uniqueness to come out and show itself more clearly.

Take Arnold Schwarzenegger for example, he has a really unique accent but he originally tried to keep it suppressed and it was just an austrian accent but once he discovered people love it, he really went hard on it and took it to an even more exaggerated level

I don't read books, I just hunt for tidbits of information and small systems. This is what helped me (in no particular order):

>The idea that depth perception is a signal generated by the brain and that *everything* you experience isn't actual reality. What you experience is a 'controlled hallucination'. Search it on youtube.
>Acting in movies and roleplaying games: the idea that you're adopting a different set of 'self', which means that there's something adopting the set of behaviors to begin with, and that there's a natural set of behaviors present in me.
>Carl Jung's cognitive functions (feeling, thinking, sensing and intuiting on the introvesion/extraversion spectrum).
>Zen Budhism and the idea that the 'you' is the consciousness, and your personality and everything else is your brain generating signals. By extension, you can influence what signals you want to generate by setting the narrative of what things 'are' with your consciousness and mindfulness.
>Also Zen Buddhism in that attachment to having certain signals means you have to have it at all costs, and actual reality means you'll use different parts of your brain to push that out, making you suffer.

These are all connected. Listen to Terence McKenna and how he talks about drugs dissolving parts of the brain

Y do u assume someone with a bible like this in front of them is verse picking? I am Christian. More specifically I am interested in 45 (Jc 9,23). And God sent an evil spirit between Abimelech and the people of Shechem. It is not easy to say if the word "sent" refers to what God commands or allows. The word that appears here is sent. The Greek has exapésteilen, a word that also appears in the psalms, where it is read: send (emitted) your light (Sal 42,3). In spite of everything, our translators, when in Greek they appear exaptereth in some places, have translated by "mandó" (misit) and not by "sent" (emisit). It can also be interpreted in the sense that God has sent an evil spirit, as if he wanted to go among them, that is, as if he had given the evil spirit power to disturb the peace that was between them. To such an extent it has not been considered as absurd that the Lord could send an evil spirit to avenge justice, that some have even translated the exapésteilen by "launched" (inmisit). Augustine

>>21593159
To be fair, Kaczynski was more extremely off-grid than Thoreau. Thoreau didn't even seek to live totally off-grid, Walden was an experiment of his to apply the Transcendentalist philosophy by living primitively for a year. For Thoreau, this did not mean fucking off far away into the woods, ceasing contact with the rest of humanity and living off the land, it simply meant simplifying the way he lived, slowly taking away more and more amenities until he found what were the true essentials. Thoreau only lived in isolation of a one mile radius, and he wrote of the importance of having visitors. He would also commute to town to work occasionally in an attempt to see how many hours of work was truly necessary to substantiate him. Self-reliance as Thoreau saw it did not mean complete self-sufficiency, but an increased reliance on oneself to achieve goodness and fulfillment, rather that reliance on industry and material items.

>>21594156

Yes yes yes. Ideally two or three at once. I did it right as a little kid, unlearned it as a young adult, and now I've re-learned it as a slightly more mature adult.

When I was a little kid I'd have two to four books going at any one time. They were simple, yes, but the basic habit was correct: have multiple ideas going on in your head all at once so that you can compare them in various unexpected and useful ways. Then as a teenager I got the general idea of Historical Order, or Linear Progression. Being trapped in the idea that things must be read in a certain order, I scarcely read after college. When I started reading again in my late 20s, I made a point of simply seeking out whatever I felt like reading. A second book, completely unrelated to the first, turned out to have unexpected connections. The same specific thing was found in both books, whatever they might have been at the time. Or other slight neural connections could be made.

When you have two or three books going, "ideas have sex with each other" in your head in way that doesn't happen with only one book. This is the value of bouncing back and forth.

Dick claims it eerily retold a story from the Book of the Acts of the Apostles in the New Testament which he didn’t know at the time of writing it, as well as, simultaneously, a later event in his own life.

>In his undelivered speech "How to Build a Universe That Doesn't Fall Apart Two Days Later," Dick recounts how in describing an incident at the end of the book (end of chapter 27) to an Episcopalian priest, the priest noted its striking similarity to a scene in the Acts of the Apostles in the Bible. In Dick's book, the police chief, Felix Buckman, meets a black stranger at an all-night gas station, and uncharacteristically makes an emotional connection with him. After handing the stranger a drawing of a heart pierced by an arrow, Buckman flies away, but he quickly returns and hugs the stranger, and they strike up a friendly conversation. In Acts Chapter 8, the disciple Philip meets an Ethiopian eunuch (a black man) sitting in a chariot, to whom he explains a passage from the Book of Isaiah, and then converts him to Christianity.

>Dick further notes that eight years after writing the book, he himself uncharacteristically came to the aid of a black stranger who had run out of gas. After giving the man some money and then driving away, he returned to help the man reach a gas station. Dick was then struck by the similarity between this incident and that described in his book.

Taverner’s dream scene was also inspired by his own dream. He also claims it prophetically, and unbeknownst to him at the time, prefigured the United States becoming a totalitarian police state.

>Dick also recounts an unusual dream he had when writing the book, and how he felt compelled to get it into the text of the novel.[7][8] Years later, he came to interpret this dream as the key to understanding the real meaning of the story, stating:

Deciphered, my novel tells a quite different story from the surface story (…). The real story is simply this: the return of Christ, now king rather than suffering servant. Judge rather than victim of unfair judgment. Everything is reversed. The core message of my novel, without my knowing it, was a warning to the powerful: You will shortly be judged and condemned.

Reading Dick’s works as a young man, including VALIS and passages of his Exegesis (a monumental and monolithic tome) actually inspired me to become a Phildickian Gnostic Christian. I think he had a genuine experience of cosmic God-consciousness. No, I will not take meds.

I found the paperback too, but Oxford/Penguin paperbacks are usually awful quality-wise… English is also not my first language so I would have to use a dictionary quite often which would make reading a paperback release even more annoying. The hardcover release also seems to be around 1200 pages longer, so the schoolarly work seems to have taken quite some effort and time:

>This is the first time that Thomas Carlyle's remarkable The French Revolution: A History has been published in a comprehensive scholarly form. The edition features an abundance of new critical features, including a critical text that presents the edition much as it appeared in the first edition of 1837, but with a detailed record of the emendations that Carlyle made in subsequent versions during his lifetime. These volumes also contain a variety of scholarly aids―literary, textual, historical, and photographic―to render The French Revolution more approachable and readable to twenty-first century readers. The edition takes seriously Carlyle's claim to have produced a history of the Revolution that is rooted in his primary French sources. The extensive annotations vividly testify to his deep engagement in a wide array of histories, pamphlets, memoirs, and biographies. The notes not only demonstrate his complex method of history, but they also shed fresh light on his artistry and his rich use of language. For the first time, readers will be provided with numerous samples of engravings that Carlyle used from Chamfort's Tableaux historiques and other sources to visualize the 'Flame Drama,' as it was conceived by revolutionary artists and printers. The appendices will also include an annotated version of Carlyle's essay, 'On the Sinking of the Vengeur' (1839), in which he offers a detailed response to controversy surrounding the events that occurred during the naval battle between France and Britain on 'the Glorious First of June,' 1794; an image and transcription of an unpublished MS holograph excerpt from The French Revolution located in the Harry Ransom Center, Texas; and a copy of a corrected proof of 'The Feast of Pikes' held in the Forster Collection of the National Art Library, Victoria and Albert Museum.

Obviously it‘s still 500 bucks though, but nonetheless I would be lying if all of this doesn‘t sound tempting. I‘d probably spend quite some time reading it, so the money feels well-spent.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21591442
>cockroach
A cockroach is an insect that is flat in shape with large legs, and Gregor is anything but flat: he is convex on both sides, belly and back, and his legs are small. He approaches a cockroach in only one respect: his coloration is brown. That is all. Apart from this he has a tremendous convex belly divided into segments and a hard rounded back suggestive of wing cases. In beetles these cases conceal flimsy little wings that can be expanded and then may carry the beetle for miles and miles in a blundering flight. Curiously enough, Gregor the beetle never found out that he had wings under the hard covering of his back. (This is a very nice observation on my part to be treasured all your lives. Some Gregors, some Joes and Janes, do not know that they have wings.) Further, he has strong mandibles. He uses these organs to turn the key in a lock while standing erect on his hind legs, on his third pair of legs (a strong little pair), and this gives us the length of his body, which is about three feet long. In the course of the story he gets gradually accustomed to using his new appendages—his feet, his feelers. This brown, convex, dog-sized beetle is very broad.

In the original German text the old charwoman calls him Mistkäfer, a "dung beetle." It is obvious that the good woman is adding the epithet only to be friendly. He is not, technically, a dung beetle. He is merely a big beetle. (I must add that neither Gregor nor Kafka saw that beetle any too clearly.)

>>21594168
>Why is it like this, /lit/?
Crazy little thing called genre fiction, which often relies on certain tropes, or variations on tropes.

The better writers breathe some degree of life into the tropes.

E.g., Stephen Hunter's Bob Lee Swagger character, or Connelly's Bosch, or Pelecanos's Derek Strange.

Now, when people read genre fiction they want something that's the same, but different. And that's what these authors supply them with. That means writing to a formula. Again, the better writers are able to breathe life into that formula.

I don't know that James Patterson has ever breathed life into anything. I rather doubt it.

posts.com:
Welcome to "The Funnel", a mind-bending graphic novel that explores the blurred lines between reality and fantasy. This first book of a seven-part series follows the journey of two sisters named Salazar ("Sal") and Alela ("Al") Coffy living in the small town of Lieh, where nothing is quite as it seems. Set against the backdrop of a cicada-filled midsummer and a local county fair, the story delves into the psyche of its characters as they navigate the supernatural and the power of language to shape and obscure meaning.

Sal, the younger sister, spends her days idling with friends and tagging along with Amy Voces, a wise and beneficent mage who lives on the far side of town. Alela, on the other hand, spends her time hiding in the woods and seeking escapism through drugs. Both sisters are unaware of the mysteries that constantly surround them and the fact that their entire understanding of reality is about to change in the worst way imaginable.

Featuring bright, detailed, psychedelic art reminiscent of 1960's underground comics and arranged via innovative panel compositions that evoke a hazy, dreamlike atmosphere, The Funnel combines elements of fantasy, horror, and magical realism to explore themes of grief, identity, and the search for meaning in a nonsensical world. Fans of Sandman, Twin Peaks and Neon Genesis Evangelion will find themselves entranced by this visually striking and thought-provoking story.


www.thefunneltapestry.com

What I noticed is that he seems good at making literature out of his reading experiences. His first two novels are a clever combination of Brautigan and Vonnegut. It goes on like this. I almost think he always has very specific models in mind when writing. There's a short story (Dabchick) where he simply rewrites Kafka's Before the Law and turns it into an absurdist comedy with a weird twist ending.

I’m not 15 anymore. There are frankly better and more important things to do with my time. If you’re a writer, you can simply reference or indicate that another language is being spoken in the text. Instead, what you should be focusing on is the story itself, the content, the themes, the message, the characters. Shitty worldbuilding hacks like Sanderson and Martin try to copy Tolkien ad nauseam, and worse, they would have you believe that mundane details like taxes, infrastructure, and sewage systems are important. This is why everything they shit out is stale. The author should have some idea about how these things work of course, but audience should mostly fill in these details for themselves.

Bottom line, just make up a few words that make sense in a template (if you absolutely must) and call it a day.
